name: Development and Platform Integration
description: A comprehensive collection of tools, libraries, and resources for software development and platform integration. This feature encompasses tools for creating, testing, and deploying applications across various frameworks, graphical environments, virtualization platforms, and development workflows. It includes libraries and tools for .NET Core, GNOME, KDE, X Window System, Xfce, and legacy components, tailored to meet the needs of developers targeting diverse platforms and technologies.

name: Desktop Environment Suites
description: A comprehensive collection of desktop environments and their associated applications, designed to cater to various usability preferences, system requirements, and user experience goals. This feature unifies traditional and modern desktop environments, lightweight interfaces for low-spec machines, and specialized user environments, all aimed at delivering intuitive and customizable graphical user experiences across devices. It includes support for GNOME technologies, traditional and elegant desktop environments like Cinnamon and Deepin, lightweight setups like LXDE and Xfce, and specialty environments such as the Sugar Learning Platform and Budgie Desktop.

name: Programming Language Support and Development
description: Provides support for using and developing software with various programming languages and tools. This feature encompasses capabilities such as developing and executing programs in multiple programming languages (e.g., Haskell, Java, OCaml, Perl, Ruby) and cross-compiling code for specific platforms like 32-bit Windows. It ensures a comprehensive programming environment for developers, offering support for both runtime systems and development tools across different platforms and languages.

name: System Utilities and Management Tools
description: A comprehensive suite of tools and utilities designed for system management, administration, hardware support, and user-specific tasks. This feature groups functionalities spanning system administration, hardware monitoring, graphical tools for system configuration, specialized tools for hardware design and production, as well as various utilities for entertainment and creative pursuits.

name: Critical Path and Extended Functionalities
description: This parent feature encompasses the essential components and utilities critical for the functionality of various Linux distributions and desktop environments, along with additional plugins and utilities used for extended capabilities. It includes packages and groups that span core system building requirements, critical path functionalities across different application domains, and desktop environment-specific critical path packages. Furthermore, it includes extended functionalities such as plugins, games, and utilities aimed at enriching the user experience.
children: Extra games for the GNOME Desktop
Extra plugins for the Xfce panel

name: Comprehensive Software Feature Suite
description: A collection of diverse software features and tools aimed at supporting modern and legacy computing environments, enabling advanced capabilities, and fostering user-friendly experiences. This suite encompasses software designed for infrastructure management, graphical and text-based content creation, educational purposes, compatibility with legacy systems, and internationalization. It addresses the needs of cloud computing, data backups, 3D printing, software editing, and more, ensuring a robust platform for a wide variety of applications and use cases.

name: Comprehensive Software and Configuration Management
description: A consolidated parent feature covering software package groups, conflict management, and specialized system configurations. This feature provides a comprehensive framework for installing, managing, and optimizing software and system configurations across various use cases, ensuring flexibility and modularity for diverse Linux environments. Key aspects include graphical and text-based tools, database management, virtualization solutions, scientific computations, and specific conflict-resolution handling for customized installations.

name: Desktop Environment and Productivity Suites
description: A comprehensive suite of features and applications that encompass office productivity tools and desktop environment-specific utilities. This feature category includes office suites for various Linux desktop environments (e.g., Deepin, KDE, LXDE, LXQt, and Xfce), standalone productivity applications like LibreOffice, tools to aid initial system configuration (e.g., KDE Spin Initial Setup), and supplementary packages like translations for specific desktop environments. Additionally, it covers specialized productivity domains, such as robotics development packages and KDE educational applications, ensuring a broad spectrum of tools tailored for both general-purpose and niche professional needs.

name: Linux Software Ecosystem and Development Support
description: A comprehensive feature set encompassing tools, libraries, frameworks, and runtime environments necessary for enabling, developing, and running applications on Linux platforms. This includes compatibility libraries for legacy support, multimedia frameworks, open-source development headers, relational databases, certificate management solutions, and language-specific interfaces to common Linux functionality.

name: System and Network Management Tools and Services
description: A comprehensive suite of tools, clients, libraries, and servers designed to support system administration, development, networking, identity management, virtualization, and high availability in modern Linux environments. This parent feature includes a wide array of functionalities for managing, developing, and interacting with both local and networked systems, while also ensuring compatibility with legacy protocols and enhanced management of identity services.

name: Network and System Service Integration
description: A comprehensive feature set that enables the system to host and support a wide variety of network-based and local system services, including name resolution, email services, file sharing, printing, web hosting, application hosting, and display management for seamless integration and operability in diverse environments. This parent feature ensures the system can act as a versatile platform to serve various IT infrastructure needs effectively.

name: Virtualization and Container Ecosystem
description: A comprehensive feature set that provides tools, utilities, and platform support for managing, deploying, and interfacing with virtualized environments and containerized applications. This parent feature encompasses a wide range of functionalities, including virtualization hypervisors, client management tools, platform-specific packages for virtualization technologies, container orchestration toolkits, and remote desktop capabilities necessary for seamless interaction with virtual systems and containers. The following sub-features are included: Docker and Kubernetes support, tools for Fedora package maintainers, virtualization utilities for Hyper-V, KVM, and VMware platforms, interfaces for virtualization guests and containers, minimal hypervisor setups, and remote desktop clients for accessing virtualized or containerized environments.

name: Linux System Core and Specialized Features
description: This parent feature encompasses core and specialized functionalities required for various Linux products and tools. It includes mandatory packages for distinct Linux product configurations (client, compute node, server, and workstation), support for ostree-based deployments (Atomic Host and Workstation), and development tools provided by PowerTools. These sub-features collectively ensure modular and comprehensive support for diverse Linux system setups and usage scenarios, accommodating both development workflows and deployment requirements.

name: Window Management and Desktop Environment Features
description: An umbrella feature encompassing support for window management systems, both standalone and integrated with desktop environments. This feature includes the X Window System, a foundation for graphical user interfaces, as well as a variety of window managers and their configurations to provide customization, flexibility, and compatibility with differing user preferences. Sub-features include lightweight window managers such as Enlightenment, Sway, XMonad, and i3, along with their supplemental packages. These tools range from basic setups to more advanced systems targeting power users and developers. Additionally, integration options for specific desktop environments such as MATE are also included. Overall, this feature is designed to cater to diverse desktop and tiling workflow requirements while supporting minimal to comprehensive package configurations.

name: Advanced Linux Feature Suite
description: A comprehensive suite of features and tools designed to provide robust support for multimedia, desktop environments, authentication mechanisms, load balancing, storage solutions, and advanced toolkit capabilities for modern Linux distributions. This parent feature ensures seamless integration, usability, and performance enhancements across various domains including system management, desktop experiences, and networking.

name: Advanced System Tools and Utilities
description: A comprehensive suite of tools and utilities designed to cater to various advanced Linux system requirements, including software development, debugging, performance optimization, networking, security, technical documentation, and scientific computing. This feature collection supports both command-line and graphical interfaces, enabling users to efficiently manage, analyze, and troubleshoot sophisticated computing environments, ranging from individual systems to large-scale mainframe and containerized infrastructures. Detailed capabilities include debugging and performance analysis for applications and large systems, network configuration and monitoring, security auditing and verification, specialized mainframe access, scientific computation support, and tools for technical documentation.

name: Enhanced Linux Desktop Ecosystem Features
description: This parent feature covers a comprehensive set of functionalities and applications to enhance the Linux desktop ecosystem. It consolidates applications, tools, utilities, and agents that are essential for various desktop environments, virtualized environments, accessibility requirements, and specialized use cases such as education and scientific computing. The feature ensures a well-rounded user experience while addressing diverse needs for desktop customization, usability, and functionality.

name: Linux Web Development and Application Stack
description: This feature represents a comprehensive Linux-based environment designed for web development and application deployment. It includes the basic Linux installation as well as tools and frameworks necessary for software development, scripting, and deploying web applications. The stack provides support for multiple programming languages, application servers, and web frameworks, making it suitable for a robust development and production environment.

name: Enhanced Graphical and Virtualization Toolkit
description: A comprehensive feature suite providing tools and packages for graphical environments and virtualization. This parent feature bundles core graphical environment packages, virtualization support (both graphical and headless), tools for professional design workflows, development aids for LibreOffice extensions/macros, and provisioning environments like Vagrant with libvirt support. It targets users who need robust graphical and virtual development capabilities.

name: Database Management and Development Tools
description: This feature encompasses a comprehensive suite of tools and products for database management, development, and operation. It includes SQL and NoSQL database solutions, database server and client applications, and compatibility with widely used database technologies such as PostgreSQL, MariaDB, and specialized offerings like Alibaba's database products and Dragonwell JDK. These tools cater to various aspects of database handling, ranging from development environments to robust server-side implementations.
